website_summaries.verdict: Loaded with details on proper power lifting, this classic weight training book is a must for all levels of lifters.
pros: Introduces beginners to power lifting and provides excellent advice on lifting with correct form
Plenty of technical info for novice, intermediate, and advanced weight training
cons: Information overload is a risk for beginners trying to learn from this book
Alternative lifting methods aren’t always explained clearly

customer_reviews.title: There is enough technical information to satisfy even the most scientific minded among us and enough ...
customer_reviews.text: I've been training with free weights off and on for 17 years and I only wish I would have read this when I first started. Priceless information in this book. Rippetoe is a legend in the strength training world and this book shows why. There is enough technical information to satisfy even the most scientific minded among us and enough clear-cut instruction to enable a complete beginner to step under a loaded barbell with confidence. Whether you've ever wanted to possess superhero strength or simply become a stronger version of yourself, you can learn all you need to get started on the path to achieving your goals.
customer_reviews.author: bigjan85

customer_reviews.title: Money well spent
customer_reviews.text: First lift I studied from this book was the dead lift,body mechanics and reaction from technic were deeply explained.I put modest weight on bar and went to work,bar over middle of foot,chest up,90deg angle of leg bones,off the floor glutes and legs engaged and every thing else,the bar went straight up to lockout,that's strange the bar felt like it only moved a foot up.that's what happens when you use his technic.I now lift with wet noodles arms and bar traveling vertical up and down.being 50 plus years old knee ,back and hip are a sensitive area,his technic spreads ld over the body,zero strain on joints for me,money well spent,can't wait to into other lifts in book.
customer_reviews.author: David J

customer_reviews.title: Strong Life Is a Happy Life
customer_reviews.text: Rippetoe's the real McCoy, a term only our (Rippetoe's and mine) age group would understand. This book was something new for me, a guy who'd never lifted before. It's a life changer, big time. After reading it cover to cover and gaining more confidence in his training thing versus my aerobic and cardio plods, I gave his a simple basic techniques a shot using only dusty dumbbells. Eureka, another term from our age group. I'm one proud novice who threw those dumbbells away a month or so later and purchased the big boy power rack and that something called a bar with plate thingeys. Rippetoe's where it's at and a strong life is a happy one when following his works...js
customer_reviews.author: JFSAZ

customer_reviews.title: Excellent advice, burried content
customer_reviews.text: I am a 67 year old male new to weight lifting. My wife purchased "Starting Strength" for me. I started over 18 months ago with squats and felt transformed physically and mentally. I added dead lifts and bench press. I credit Mark for getting me started with his book. His book has helped me refine my squat form, dead lift habits, and over head press. I go back to the book when aches and pains start and I find again I have deviated from ideal form. I continue to marvel at the benefits from improved core strength! The book could benefit from a good editor. It could be half as long and more fun to read.
customer_reviews.author: Carol Fairchild

customer_reviews.title: I'm married and happy. So anyway
customer_reviews.text: This book inspired me. I've shared it with everyone I know who wants to train in the gym for strength. Form is king. Understanding the in's and out's of your posture and how to work through all the motions of barbell training is critical to developing proper form. I've gotten tens of chicks as a result of my massive gains. Ok that part is a lie. I'm married and happy. So anyway, I am stronger and better focused on how to get proper results after reading this book. Props to Mark Rippetoe... that guy has a painful sounding name but knows what he's doing here. Read up.
customer_reviews.author: Bloop McFloop

customer_reviews.title: Best in 60 years
customer_reviews.text: I am a 76 year old retired physician with a lifetime interest in and practice of recreational resistance training. This is simply the best, in every way, introduction to the theory and practice of recreational resistance training that I have ever seen--clearest and most complete explanations of "why" some practices are good and others not so much, best teaching methods for "how" to power lift, clearest illustrations (photos and drawings), best factually grounded theory. Especially, if you are helping or plan to help a novice get into resistance training, you need to share this book with your pupil.
customer_reviews.author: Customer

customer_reviews.title: Not as Good as I was Hoping
customer_reviews.text: I like Rip, and I really wanted to like this book, but I just didnt. I bought it to learn about the SS method. This book pretty much only covers the lifts and provides far more information than I feel an average beginner really needs. The writing is rambling at times, almost like stream of consciousness writing. I really feel the book needed a good editor to help cut down on some of the unnecessary bits. If you want to learn the lifts, it would be better to watch Rip teach it on youtube. There is very little information on programming or the SS method here. If you want that info, you need to look at Practical Programming (same author).
customer_reviews.author: Brian D. Russell

customer_reviews.title: Great reference for proper barbell form and strength training.
customer_reviews.text: Most of the book is teaching correct form for the low-bar squat, deadlift, overhead press, flat bench press, power clean, and power snatch with some auxiliary exercises like pull-ups and curls. The final (smaller) segment deals with strength training programming and a bit about diet. I would have liked if the book expanded here, which is why I'm forced to by Rip's second book on the topic. My favorite parts were the author jumping from rigid technical terms on anatomy and physics to laymen jargon and banter. Next time I see someone lifting with gloves, I'll finish my squat set, polish off my gallon of milk, and ask him if they match his purse.
customer_reviews.author: Patrick

customer_reviews.title: Great Resource
customer_reviews.text: Not much programming in this book, but the discussion of the lifts and the benefits of barbell training are as good as I've come across in 18 years of lifting. I wish I would have come across this when I was starting out as it has helped me correct a lot of small defects in my form. Good for serious lifters and people who want to learn to lift for fitness.

customer_reviews.title: Not a casual read, but an in depth manual.
customer_reviews.text: Excellent, and very thorough book on major lifts. Be advised that this is essentially a textbook. I guess I wasn't aware when I got it that it is this in depth. Seriously. The squat section is 71 pages, double columns. Many pictures and illustrations, though. While it seemed at first bite that I was getting in way over my head, the information has stuck, and I refer often to the principals during my training.
customer_reviews.author: Ashley Lande

customer_reviews.title: Excellent weight lifting book
customer_reviews.text: This is an excellent reference book for 5 major weightlifting moves that will make you strong everywhere. Contrary to any Men's Fitness article it has way more detail than you can probably handle on any one of these moves, but that makes it great for beginners looking to learn the lifts and experienced lifters working to improve nuances to decrease pain and increase weight. The book does an excellent job of explaining the physiology/anatomy as well as the physics at work with each move. Rather than just tell you how to do a lift, the book explains why you do it that way.
customer_reviews.author: Me

customer_reviews.title: Essential reading for barbell training
customer_reviews.text: This book is great for a novice lifter or someone who has been at it for years and is looking to clean up their form. I am in the later category and this book was extremely helpful for cleaning up my squat form which I struggled with for years. The instructions are simple and clear and cover the major barbell movements. If you experience back pain after deadlifts or squats, you are probably doing them wrong. Pick this up to correct or avoid these pitfalls all together. Cannot recommend enough.
customer_reviews.author: Joshua Jakubczak

customer_reviews.title: Excellent Tool for the Serious Lifter
customer_reviews.text: I have been reviewing this book and have found its content is EXTREMELY helpful if you are serious about learning the proper technique/form to properly lift weights. Its explanations of bio-mechanics and the function of the muscles in the body during the lifts (particularly squats and dead-lifts), as well as proper posturing, will help anyone to focus on proper form, so as to prevent injuries. An excellent investment to better health and safety in the gym!!!!
customer_reviews.author: DLC

customer_reviews.title: Great for beginners
customer_reviews.text: Perfect book for a beginner. I always stayed away from the free weights portion of the gym since I was not confident enough that I was doing it right, and I was afraid of injuries. This book made a whole lot of difference to that mindset. I have been doing it now for a month, and I cant wait to hit the gym again. Make sure you watch his youtube videos as the book tends to be technical. For the first week, there's gonna be1 or 2 muscle heads in the gym that will tell you that you are doing it wrong, specially with the squat. Just nod and smile.
customer_reviews.author: Pnoymd

customer_reviews.title: A comprehensive, no-BS guide to getting stronger using barbells.
customer_reviews.text: With an internet full of "trainers" peddling fad-workouts, misinformation, and "get in shape quick" schemes, it can be very hard to know what to do in the gym. This book is the answer to that. It will teach you the lifts and methods that actually work, and the best way to do them, as determined by the author's 30+ years of experience working with beginners. He has seen what works, and has seen what does not work. If you want to start working-out, do yourself a favor and learn from Rip's life-work. Read this book, and its companion, Practical Programming.
customer_reviews.author: MATTHEW T MILLER

customer_reviews.title: The Bible of Weightlifting, but Poorly Written
customer_reviews.text: I had problems with the writing, but this is the bible that in my experience serious lifters follow. There's controversy about the Valsava maneuver, but there appears to be zero empirical evidence that Valsalva while weightlifting cam cause a severe adverse event. My doc said it's an old wives' tale. A cautious person may want to be screened for pre-existing cardiovascular problems and high blood pressure. I like that this edition has pictures of a woman demonstrating.
customer_reviews.author: SueDonym

customer_reviews.title: Outstanding detail!
customer_reviews.text: I hurt my back when I was much younger doing squats, since then I avoided any similar exercise that might jeopardize my back. That meant I avoid squats and deadlifts at a minimum. Realizing the importance of deadlifts and squats in building strength I found "Starting Strength." This well written, detailed book gave me the confidence start a program involving squats and deadlifts (to start) and build strength in my body that I previously ignored. I look forward to "learning" other lifts described in this well written and detailed book.
customer_reviews.author: Charles Garcia

customer_reviews.title: Must have if you plan on using a barbell
customer_reviews.text: There are millions of people advocating for barbell training for a variety of reasons. Short and simple, if you plan on using a barbell, you should read this book. If you want to improve your technique for any of the lifts mentioned in the description, you should read this book. Even if you don't plan on entering a strength sport but intend to train with barbells, you really should read this book.
customer_reviews.author: Travis Robe

customer_reviews.title: The Weightlifter’s Bible
customer_reviews.text: Required reading for anyone lifting weights for strength. Excellent coverage of the major compound barbell movements. Coverage includes proper form, anatomy, biomechanics fundamental strength programming and more in a very easy to digest and succinct form. Reading this book helped me eliminate reoccurring injuries I had from using improper form and allowed me to continue regular progression. Posterior Chain FTW
customer_reviews.author: Shawn H

customer_reviews.title: If you want to get Strong. READ THIS BOOK.
customer_reviews.text: This book is absolutely amazing! I have never been good at Squats, and this book has a 70 page section on the Squat. Since reading it and watching many of the videos, the Squat has become one of my favorite lifts and am touching numbers I was once afraid of. I have never found another book this in depth and detailed. I honestly want to buy it again just so I can get the Hard copy as well!
customer_reviews.author: Daxis

customer_reviews.title: If only the author were not quite so biased on topics OTHER THAN his sport
customer_reviews.text: Seems like a pretty good work about using barbells, but a lot of the opinions and offhand remarks the author makes are borderline offensive. I couldn't get through it.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Stitcher

customer_reviews.title: 60 days' results
customer_reviews.text: I'm a mom who has had two abdominal surgeries, a spinal fusion surgery, and a shattered heel that has never healed properly. Lifting weights was the last thing on my mind. For me, maintaining good health consisted of keeping my weight down (Why we Get Fat by Gary Taubes) and low-impact exercise (biking, swimming). A visit to aging relatives opened my eyes. Balance, coordination, physical degeneration. A link from Instapundit led me to this book. I've been lifting for 60 days, three times per week, and the differences are notable. Recommended.
customer_reviews.author: M. Heiss

customer_reviews.title: Good introduction to powerlifting but Olympic lifters look elsewhere
customer_reviews.text: This is a perfect introduction to barbell training. The writing is precise and there are many photos that make the points clear. If you are more advanced into powerlifting you may still find this book helpful. If you are more advanced and moving into the sport of Olympic style weightlifting, then this book will not be as useful in learning the Olympic lifts
customer_reviews.author: Jason Ehlers

customer_reviews.title: Thorough, definitive, outstanding
customer_reviews.text: If you want to learn how to train for strength with a barbell using compound exercises, you can do no better than Starting Strength. If you want to learn how to crossfit, get pumped and flex, or complete one thousand ab crunches, you should move on down the road. The Good: All of the major compound exercises, explained in gory detail, are here for the learning. You'll learn the what, how and often the why of squats, deadlifts, and presses. The Bad: May be too much detail for some, and the illustrations look a bit amateurish, with handwriting instead of printed text labels. This is a very minor criticism though. Get this book and get strong.
customer_reviews.author: J. Loupe

customer_reviews.title: Highly recommended for the beginning weight lifter
customer_reviews.text: Highly recommended for the beginning weight lifter. Keep in mind that the material is extremely dense and the programming guide is available online through a google search. There is an incredible amount of detail in the book on proper form, which can be supplemented through searching for Rippetoe video's on youtube. As a reference tool, "Starting Strength" is an incredible resource. Reading the book straight through, however, is a challenging endeavor. The material is very dry and dense and requires some knowledge of anatomy or constant referencing to understand some of the concepts.
customer_reviews.author: Gibby

customer_reviews.title: Great Book
customer_reviews.text: I've just completed week 5 of this program and am amazed at the results. I'm not putting on 5 pounds a week, thankfully, but I'm getting stronger with every work out. One of the best aspects of the book is the amount of detail put into explaining the proper way to do the lift, especially the squat. The only criticism I have is that the program focuses more on lower body than upper body. Still, my upper body is getting stronger too. The book is great, especially if you have never worked out or if you were the kind of person who always skipped leg days, like I did.
customer_reviews.author: Dan

customer_reviews.title: 135 squat to 225
customer_reviews.text: Great book written in terms we can all understand and practice. I have progressed from 135 squat to 225 in about 6 weeks! I am 160lb, 41 years old male and I like how Ripp is old and hurt and teaches you how not to end up like him...lol. If you are a beginner you may want to check out this program. There is nothing like getting to a 225 squat for reps..
customer_reviews.author: Rackedout

customer_reviews.title: The only powerlifting book you NEED.
customer_reviews.text: This is pretty much the bible for powerlifting. I love Mark Rippetoe's no-nonsense style and it inspired me to actually become a personal trainer myself. This book is pretty much all you need to achieve a basic to advanced level of strength and is designed with the beginner in mind. It shows you each lift from the ground up. It would still be great to seek out a competent trainer who could help you learn the lifts, but this book is a must have for anyone seriously. I went from having a terrible, pitiful, puny half-depth squat with half my body weight to repping double my body weight in the span of six months.
customer_reviews.author: Icy Mike

customer_reviews.title: Rippetoe is on the mark
customer_reviews.text: This is the very first - and in my opinion the best - book everyone should start with when working out with barbells. This book should be read by everyone who does any barbell work in their training program. Some parts of the book were a little difficult at first - you can skip over those and come back to them. But read the book cover to cover. Then refer back to it from time to time periodically to refresh yourself on good technique. This book does not take the place of a good trainer, but at least you'll know if you have a good trainer after reading this book.
customer_reviews.author: Green Thumb

customer_reviews.title: Best Book for New Lifters
customer_reviews.text: Helped me put on much more muscle and strength in just a few months than I did during an entire year of doing typical bro splits. The explanations of the technique were also very helpful especially for people who think they can't squat/deadlift because of bad knees or back problems. Chances are you can actually do these exercises if you start with a low enough weight and perform them correctly.
customer_reviews.author: David

customer_reviews.title: Great introduction to the world of weight lifting
customer_reviews.text: Weightlifting can dramatically enhance your life if you do it right, But also can cause chronic injuries and leave you worse than you started, if you do it wrong. This book gives you all the tools to do it right from the start. It's intended for those who are not afraid of details and can practice with discipline exactly as this book guides you.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Excellent guide. I feel stronger after two weeks of ...
customer_reviews.text: Excellent guide. I feel stronger after two weeks of Starting Strength than after months of aimless, barbell-lacking workouts. However, you should keep in mind that you can get the contents of the book on your phone by buying the Starting Strength app, which you'll probably want anyways if you do the program.
customer_reviews.author: Red M.

customer_reviews.title: Became a huge Rippetoe fan
customer_reviews.text: Loved Rip's writing style and the knowledge he passes on. Great for all levels. Sometimes it takes him a while to get to a point, but I found that there is a reason he is going through the material he is presenting, if you pay attention. I read Practical Programming after this book and follow his website / Twitter closely.
customer_reviews.author: Mac

customer_reviews.title: Life changing
customer_reviews.text: Read the book and follow the program, you won't be disappointed. Be consistent and develop a great, rewarding, and fun habit. Train for awhile then read the book again. I am a small, older fellow and the compliments I get on my physique are amazing. Not enough credit is given to the improving changes in your hormones from following the program. Body fat percentage went down rather quickly for me personally. Now I am gaining weight mostly as pure muscle. Get STRONG!
customer_reviews.author: Michael

customer_reviews.title: Thorough book
customer_reviews.text: Well written .... concise explanations of what you're doing and why ..... plenty of pictures and diagrams to show the proper mechanics of each exercise ...... how to do it rightly without injury ...... great book for beginners
customer_reviews.author: Mark E

customer_reviews.title: What he said
customer_reviews.text: Move around, that's exercise. Distract yourself from other concerns and relate to other people, say by holding weight over your head, that's recreation. Strive to improve along a dimension you predict and measure, that's training. Try to do better than someone else or everyone else, that is competition. Mark Rippetoe suggests that exercise, recreation and competition will all improve when you train. Lifting a barbell is the way that homo sapiens sapiens become incrementally stronger on purpose. Mark is a trained anthropologist who knows how to observe by participating, in light of what we know about our species. If you like to exercise, relax, or compete at anything, following his instruction will improve your life.
customer_reviews.author: Dan Duffy

customer_reviews.title: If you have never done strength training and getting into CrossFit at a not young age like me, read this first
customer_reviews.text: If you are thinking about CrossFit read this first. If you are thinking about strength training read this first. If you have never done strength training and getting into CrossFit at a not young age like me, read this first.
customer_reviews.author: O. Jordan

customer_reviews.title: Weightlifter version of The Bible.
customer_reviews.text: If you want to learn how to bench, squat, and deadlift (and why wouldn’t you), purchase. this. book. Rip has been in the game for longer than I’ve been alive and this book will help you dial in your technique. Just a little FYI, don’t follow anything he has to say about nutrition, because it’s all garbage advice.
customer_reviews.author: Mike

customer_reviews.title: Good guide
customer_reviews.text: This book was mentioned as a good reference in BIGGER, LEANER, STRONGER. It is more technical and, therefore, the second book one should read. Your knowledge of anatomy will increase along with the techniques of strength training with barbells. A great resource once you've been introduced to the basic skills!
customer_reviews.author: steve

customer_reviews.title: The best material for understanding the basic barbell movements
customer_reviews.text: This book offers all the information necessary to performing the basic barbell movements, it is structured in such a way that it teaches you how to do them and then shows you the most common mistakes related to the lifts. I have been training for about 3 years, I've learned the lifts through youtube mostly and I always felt like I didn't quite get the whole picture, but after reading this book I am confident that I have the right knowledge to improve my technique. I would recommend this to any beginner and to people who want know in detail how to perform this movements correctly.
customer_reviews.author: Vicentiu Nicolae

customer_reviews.title: The best beginning book for powerlifting, period.
customer_reviews.text: I have competed in raw powerlifting for 2 years, my trainer has trained a world champion and multiple world record holder, despite that, this book completely changed my technique and workouts. Now no injuries, much much better technique, my central nervous system is no longer shattered all the time. My workouts are a little shorter, the diet is more straight forward. Whilst this book is aimed towards beginning strength trainers, I recommend all beginning and intermediate powerlifter, and even some advanced lifters, to study this book. In the kidle version which I have there must be about 50 pages just on proper deadlift technique, similarly for the other lifts. Stop dallying about just buy this book now.
customer_reviews.author: Kiwi

customer_reviews.title: Good book to guide one along the journey of beginning weight lifting.
customer_reviews.text: Not the best but a good guide to get one started in the learning of weight lifting. It will not lead you wrong and you will learn good basic principles that will aid you down the road as you become more experienced.
customer_reviews.author: Joseph R. Lang

customer_reviews.title: Excellent for getting your form correct.
customer_reviews.text: I fully believe Ripp's lifting advice, it is great if you're serious about lifting and want to get your squat, deadlift, ohp, bench, and power clean to perfect form. He even goes into detail on some accessory lifts like curling and good mornings. And it is very helpful to read why the SS program is great for beginners, it gives you something to believe in as you work out as opposed to trying something different at the gym everyday and not knowing if you're actually getting stronger. But don't listen to his diet advice. If you want to know how to eat, go to the fitness board on 4chan and read the sticky (first post) it is worth it.
customer_reviews.author: Danny Boy

customer_reviews.title: Proper form based on human anatomy. Good stuff.
customer_reviews.text: I’ve really enjoyed this book. I read Bigger Leaner Stronger by Mike Matthews first and this book has really solidified my form. I’m new to weightlifting and I’ve made good gains as I’ve learned how to do the lifts properly. I’d recommend it for sure.
customer_reviews.author: Nick F

customer_reviews.title: Lift for life.
customer_reviews.text: Just reading the first chapter has changed my approach to lifting and as a result I started hitting PR's immediately. Mark Rippetoe understands physiology better than anyone on the planet. Matter of fact, if you study the picture on the cover enough, that alone will improve your squatting powers. Must have.
customer_reviews.author: DJ PSYCHIC

customer_reviews.title: The Best
customer_reviews.text: This is by far the best program I have used. I have seem dramatic gains in the two months that I have been using it and I am still adding weights to the bar every session. Rippetoe is very thorough in explaining the exercises and the theories behind them.
customer_reviews.author: enkidu25

customer_reviews.title: the BIBLE for weight lifting
customer_reviews.text: This is an AMAZING read! This book has literally changed my life. It is so well written, with an astounding amount of detailed information on classic weight training exercises. Rippetoe is candid and definitely opinionated, but he backs it up with copious detail and facts. The author occasionally throws in some dry humor to keep things from getting too dry, and when he does it is absolutely hilarious to boot. The lifts are hard and require practice to execute, but if you do them right, you WILL get strong without injuring yourself. This should be the Bible for gym goers.
customer_reviews.author: ChefBum

customer_reviews.title: Excellent Training Manual
customer_reviews.text: An excellent introduction to barbell training, and particularly the squat exercise. Do not start squatting without getting qualified instructions. You can mess yourself up bad with poor form! That said, the Starting Strength System seems to attract a very opinionated group that adhere to their beliefs and philosophy with a near religious zeal. There are other valid opinions and methods out there. This is an excellent place to start.
customer_reviews.author: Rick

customer_reviews.title: A great book for beginning and advanced lifters
customer_reviews.text: I have been lifting weights somewhat successfully for many years. Yet, now I am learning something on nearly every page. I bought this book to help me teach my kids the right way to lift. I have not been disappointed.
customer_reviews.author: Blaine Butcher

customer_reviews.title: This is THE book to get when starting weightlifting
customer_reviews.text: Rip is the expert. The book is highly useful for understanding how everything works, rather than telling you what to do. Use in conjunction with Rip's videos on YouTube. Should be required reading for every weightlifting trainer.
customer_reviews.author: Steven T. Kirsch

customer_reviews.title: Good book
customer_reviews.text: Good book for beginners. I’m 55 and been lifting since I was 15 so I’ve learned a lot through trial and error. I don’t agree with everything Mr Rippetoe says but he knows power lifting.
customer_reviews.author: CanaTCT

customer_reviews.title: the definitive book on novice training
customer_reviews.text: If you only read one book on strength training or weight lifting, this is the one. It is the definitive book and how-to guide. It’s jam packed with all the info you need, and nothing you don’t. Basically all of the fitness youtubers are rehashing this content.
customer_reviews.author: mdelvecchio

customer_reviews.title: Holy Grail of the Compound Barbell Movements
customer_reviews.text: I train with an SSC 3x/wk and I wouldn't change it for the world. However I still want to be able to truly learn and understand the How's and Why's of the lifts which is why I bought this book. I love Anatomy & Physiology and Physics so this book is right up my alley. It might be a tad dry and might also involve tons of Googling if/when you come across a more technical term you're unfamiliar with but you will learn and hopefully get stronger, I know I have!
customer_reviews.author: leah

customer_reviews.title: Without a doubt the leading book for strength building
customer_reviews.text: Without a doubt the leading book for strength building. For a novice do it yourself type the technical physiology is a little heavy for me but the accuracy of the training techniques is vital to avoid harming myself, or yourself. If you are serious about building or re-building strength buy and study it.
customer_reviews.author: D. Hamp

customer_reviews.title: Valuable information
customer_reviews.text: Mark is right on the money with his lifting/health philosophy. Great valuable information. A must read for anyone interested in their health especially for people over 40
customer_reviews.author: JT

customer_reviews.title: A Confidence Builder
customer_reviews.text: After hiring personal trainers to assist with my weightlifting I found this book to be much more helpful than any of the personal trainers that I hired over the years. Being a novice weightlifter I developed a confidence in using the correct form when weightlifting after reading this book. Incredible detail regarding the why's and how's of lifting weights. One of the best books I've read on the topic. It has earned the five star rating.
customer_reviews.author: Option Guy

customer_reviews.title: This book is my coach.
customer_reviews.text: I train alone. This book is my coach. I have highlighted and tagged pages in it so when something doesn't feel right, I can refer to the book. There's a TON of information in this book, and it can be a hard read at times. Rippetoe has some opinions that take several pages to discuss as well, but thats ok. It is THE go to source if you want to get started with weightlifting. Even for people like me who have been lifting for a awhile, it will show you everything you've been doing wrong for all those years!
customer_reviews.author: PMH

customer_reviews.title: Exactly what I needed!
customer_reviews.text: This book was extremely helpful on helping me to understand proper body mechanics and lifting form. I used to get injured periodically when lifting and now I don't. This book has helped me stay on track with functional strength gains without injury delays and setbacks.
customer_reviews.author: Troy Beck

customer_reviews.title: A must read
customer_reviews.text: I wish I would've been introduced to this book two decades ago. Had I, maybe my back and shoulders wouldn't have been destroyed by bad form (or at the very least they would've been strengthened for life activities)
customer_reviews.author: Brandon Romeo

customer_reviews.title: Must Buy!
customer_reviews.text: C'mon, its Rip! This is a staple in so many strength coaches and athletes library's. I am ashamed it took me so long to buy it. He is a master at his craft and in an age of so much misleading fitness fads and hyperbole, the facts in this book stand up under the scrutiny of time and sports performance. Highly recommend.
customer_reviews.author: Doug F.

customer_reviews.title: Rippetoe is a very thorough teacher
customer_reviews.text: This book is a must have for any weight lifter's library. Rippetoe not only tells you exactly how to do the lifts correctly but his goes into very great detail about why you need to do it that way. Some of the things he goes into about body mechanics are pretty hard to follow if you are like me and know very little about anatomy, but it is a great read none the less. I would also recommend getting the companion DVD. I learned a lot by reading about the lift in the book and then immediately watching that section of the DVD pertaining to that chapter before I moved on to the next chapter in the book.
customer_reviews.author: Tcul1972

customer_reviews.title: This book is thorough!
customer_reviews.text: To say this book is thorough is is an understatement, it goes beyond thorough. Mr. Rippetoe covers the most intricate movements of the big lifts to the point that it borders on information overload. At times I felt like I was reading a science text. I just wanted pointers on how to do the lifts correctly, you get that and more. I agree that if you plan to lift weights as exercise then you absolutely need to have this book in your library. It's a great reference tool.
customer_reviews.author: FreeFriFriddlyFrum

customer_reviews.title: Highly recommend for new lifters
customer_reviews.text: Great book for proper lifting technique. I was new to lifting last year and spent 6 months going from injury to injury - elbow, knee, back hurting, shoulder etc. I was going too high weight before getting the form. This book and other research helped that tremendously. Since the beginning of this year I've used a variant of Starting Strength programming and the techniques shown, and have been able to progress nicely with no more than soreness.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Professional Slug
customer_reviews.text: I hate aerobics classes for any reason, running for no reason, bouncing without reason, and any excessive springing and all the other nonsense that goes on at a gym or in exercise home videos. I pick things up and put them down for most everything I do except sitting at a desk or eating. I can do a barbell even if it is empty, especially when it is empty. I can do a squat, a deadlift, I love the geometry in which he explains proper angles. Thanks Mark, now I have no excuse for continuing my life of avoiding work.
customer_reviews.author: rebecca adams

customer_reviews.title: Get this book
customer_reviews.text: I don't care what else you do with your life, read this book, and engage. I've been weight training for over 40 years, and this is the best book, by far, that I've ever read on building strength, which is the basis for a healthy life.
customer_reviews.author: KLM

customer_reviews.title: Great read, highly recommend for developing your lifting foundation
customer_reviews.text: Excellent book whether you're just starting to lift, or have been lifting for a while but hear a lot of conflicting advice regarding proper form. Tells you his critique of different forms, and why he advises using which ones he does. Then gives a very good breakdown of how to do each lift properly (his way) and how to check to see if you are. As the title says, this is for strength training, and I highly recommend it for beginners or folks who want to reestablish a foundation. If you're lifting for aesthetics, you may add more upper body movements to his routine, but you can always do that later.
customer_reviews.author: Ken

customer_reviews.title: It does such a wonderful job describing the lifts that you almost don't need ...
customer_reviews.text: Wow, what a thorough book. If you've every wondered if your doing a lift right or wrong, just read this. It does such a wonderful job describing the lifts that you almost don't need pictures. It's one I go back to from time to time and learn and refine my technique.
customer_reviews.author: Brian

customer_reviews.title: Great for technique, only okay for programming
customer_reviews.text: This is great for learning and visualization of proper form, and shows you smart accessory movements to add to your routine. However, I wish it went more in depth in regards to building a program.
customer_reviews.author: Evan Nicely

customer_reviews.title: A must read IMO for trainers
customer_reviews.text: I like Rippentoe. His style is not for everyone and he has his detractors. I find his material sound and straight forward so it suits me.
customer_reviews.author: mj868

customer_reviews.title: Great way to start a strength program
customer_reviews.text: Great way to start a strength program. I bought for my son who is getting ready to play high school football. Learning how to do those big exercises - dead lifts, squats, etc. - correctly was a big help. I read it too and decided to drop the machine workouts I was wasting my time on and go back to barbell basics. I feel better and stronger for it. Rip has some excellent videos on youtube that are a good companion to the book to help learn the correct movements.
customer_reviews.author: Old Soldier

customer_reviews.title: Book of Strength
customer_reviews.text: A great easy read, one of the most basic cornerstones of lifting when you either get started or you're simply wanting to improve your technique for the 3 basic lifts. I recommend this book to all my friends who start lifting or want to learn right ways
customer_reviews.author: Marco M.

customer_reviews.title: Very detailed and easily understood. Didn't know anyone could go into so ...
customer_reviews.text: Book arrived timely and packaging was not damaged. Very detailed and easily understood. Didn't know anyone could go into so much detail and write so much on just 5 basic compound exercises that many people overlook while training for strength. Definitely recommended for anyone who'd like to embark on a strength training program!
customer_reviews.author: Calvin Sng

customer_reviews.title: This will help you develop.
customer_reviews.text: Clear, direct, expertly presented. Weight training is about form and heavy lifting. This is replete with photographs, diagrams, caveats, and how-tos. The big Five of lifting, but presented from every possible angle.
customer_reviews.author: TheLyingThief

customer_reviews.title: I'm glad I was recommended this book to read
customer_reviews.text: I was always afraid to start lifting on my own without a coach because of not knowing proper form. I'm glad I was recommended this book to read. It goes into A LOT of detail about each lift. I started my workout routine in my garage about two weeks ago and I have the confidence that I'm doing the lifts correctly with good form so I can avoid injury. I go back to the book every once in a while to re-read sections to make sure I'm doing everything right.
customer_reviews.author: T. Waltz

customer_reviews.title: Not for the crossfit crowd
customer_reviews.text: This book is from lifting coach Mark Rippetoe and contains everything you need to know about strength training. If you follow this book and eat right; you will see results. There is no two ways about it; I've purchased this book several times and given it out as gifts to those people in life who "want to get into shape" and are serious about it. You will get stronger. No Gimmicks like Crossfit or rope training. Nothing dangerous involved, as this book teaches proper form. The best way, for guys AND girls to get into lifting.
customer_reviews.author: Whoistcmt

customer_reviews.title: I'm a newbie to Barbell Strength Training and this book is great!
customer_reviews.text: This book gives me the basic knowledge to Barbell Strength Training! As Mark Rippetoe say's even you 80 yr. old grandmother can get stronger! Great book!
customer_reviews.author: R. Forester

customer_reviews.title: Good Form 101
customer_reviews.text: Confession time, I finally learned how to lift. It actually is a little too @nal to be honest but in order to learn you should have all the information. This is not some guru's opinion on what you should do. It is all scientific and with all the reason as to why and how. It definitely helped me. I had to decrease drastically the weight but by doing it correctly it actually feels like I increased the weight and tension time. Stop working out and start training. One of the best investments I ever made on training.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: This book sets the standard for your basic lifting.
customer_reviews.text: Not just exercises, but how to perform them properly so that you gain maximum benefits and not get hurt. Think 'best practices' for strength training.
customer_reviews.author: James Perales

customer_reviews.title: Highly recommended.
customer_reviews.text: This is a very comprehensive guide to building foundational strength. It's straightforward and it explains in great detail why each recommendation is made, based on the physics of each exercise and the recruitment of various muscle groups for various movements. Highly recommend.
customer_reviews.author: Kody A.

customer_reviews.title: Basic and excellent
customer_reviews.text: A good basic guide to barbell training -- nothing fancy or trendy, just tried-and-true instruction on how to use barbells correctly. I appreciate the emphasis on proper form because, after all, who wants to get injured? I can't get this book out of my daughter's hands so I might have to buy another one for myself. By the way, though I read almost everything these days on my Kindle, I bought a hard copy of this book because I like to flip through it, sort of like a cookbook. I just think a hard copy is more conducive to reading this type of manual.
customer_reviews.author: MJfromNJ

customer_reviews.title: If you want to learn how to get strong, this is where you start.
customer_reviews.text: My first and most enlightening strength book I've ever owned. Definitely broke down the basics of the big three and helped me lift with a purpose. Initially appreciated some of the humor and entertaining anecdotes, but later down the line I found it hard to re-read. Great first book for learning to lift. Get Practical Programming with this, and after about 6-12 months, read that one, too.
customer_reviews.author: Kevin M Bania

customer_reviews.title: Must have
customer_reviews.text: Fantastic book covering the basic barbell movements in great detail. Ripp can be a verbose at times and I found myself getting lost in the details, but still a great book and something every fitness person should own
customer_reviews.author: Justin

customer_reviews.title: The book's content is easy to cross-reference with any number of other resources (books ...
customer_reviews.text: Very comprehensive. Reading it closely and recording my lifting sessions have significantly improved my form. The book's content is easy to cross-reference with any number of other resources (books / internet / video) to be able to lift safely.
customer_reviews.author: ML Tross

customer_reviews.title: Must read for any level of fitness
customer_reviews.text: Rip is rock solid when it comes to establishing the basis for lifting. A lifetime of experience combined with his no nonsense Texas attitude makes for a real treasure of a book. Pair it with Practical Programming for Starting Strength and you've got the recipe for a healthier, stronger, and more fulfilling way to live.
customer_reviews.author: SteveA

customer_reviews.title: Essential reading for people starting with barbells
customer_reviews.text: This covers a few important lifts and describe variants that are the best (in the sense of being most well rounded). It is a great introduction. There are also VERY good videos, a strong social community, and gym resources at their Starting Strength web site.
customer_reviews.author: Brennan H Evans

customer_reviews.title: Amazing!
customer_reviews.text: Amazing! The best overall educational investment I have made in strength training material. I immediately purchased a hard copy after reading the Kindle version to have around as a reference for myself and others. Thank you Mr. Rippetoe!
customer_reviews.author: Robert Ladd

customer_reviews.title: Learn the proper way to lift heavy weight
customer_reviews.text: This book, along with youtube videos with Mark Rippetoe, are a great way to learn the very few exercises you need to get really strong. His other book, Practical Programming for Strength Training, is also a must read.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Good Program but I've switched
customer_reviews.text: Good program, but I've switched to Tactical Barbell for my strength work, and I use Pavel's Simple and Sinister + anaerobic conditioning for the rest. I'm a SWAT member, so I need something a little more applicable to my specific needs. I can't drink a gallon of milk a day, and my rest and recovery isn't always optimal. If you don't have these issues then this program will get you sorted out. As a side note,I love Rippetoe's perspective on Crossfit - he is bang on in my humble opinion. Crossfit won't get you as strong as a proper progressive strength program will.
customer_reviews.author: Whiskey Bravo

customer_reviews.title: Possibly the most detailed information available on earth on power ...
customer_reviews.text: Possibly the most detailed information available on earth on power lifting and how to do the 5 big lifts properly. I now understand the physiology of lifting.
customer_reviews.author: ted r

customer_reviews.title: Buy it.
customer_reviews.text: Well written. Makes sense for normal people. Author clearly understands who his intended audience is.
customer_reviews.author: Brian

customer_reviews.title: Opinions are like phasers -- everybody ought to have one.
customer_reviews.text: Here is my opinion - I mean phaser! Mark Rippetoe is one funny guy! I've just gotten through the introduction and loved the material so far. His sense of humor intermingled with what I hope is a serious dive into how I can improve my strength is a welcome approach from the serious tones I've encountered before. I will provide more updates as I read. For more wit and wisdom :
customer_reviews.author: RVB3

customer_reviews.title: Must-read for any serious trainee
customer_reviews.text: An absolute must-read for any serious trainee regardless of age, and particularly beneficial for sports requiring explosive strength. Covers the important barbell exercises and their correct technique. Thankfully, you can also find on YouTube additional instruction on technique. Search for "rippetoe". If you could only own a single book on strength training, this should be it.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Excellent book for strength training
customer_reviews.text: Great book for learning the basics of strength training. Would recommend to everyone who wants to be stronger and more capable in life.
customer_reviews.author: Daniel W.

customer_reviews.title: Very thorough
customer_reviews.text: This book gave me some great tips to improve my deadlift and squat. I would recommend this to a novice or advanced lifter.
customer_reviews.author: Ray N

customer_reviews.title: barbell training is BIG MEDICINE.
customer_reviews.text: about 2 years of Texas method ; I feel.indestructible. this is one of those books that if you read carefully paying.lots of atrention to what the aujthors are telling you ,you will havthe time of your life .I love how athletic i was able to feel.at age 29 after starting training with the barbell the Starting Strength way at age 27(never before in my life I..had the opportunity to feel this Athletic.
customer_reviews.author: Erwin

customer_reviews.title: Best strength training book, period
customer_reviews.text: If you're looking for a book to help you get healthier and no BS, this is the one. Rippetoe makes a thorough investigation of what matters when you want to focus on what's important to have a healthier body, without the BS that most of the books have, with all nonsense targeted to bodybuilding.
customer_reviews.author: H. Fontana

customer_reviews.title: It feels funny at first but makes perfect sense after you see ...
customer_reviews.text: Squat has gone up over 80 lbs in past two months. All other lifts with decent gains with this program. It feels funny at first but makes perfect sense after you see some gains. It's all about rest when you're over 45 I guess. Easy to read. Straight forward. Sometimes he's a little pretentious and elite, but It really is simple.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Worth the money and more.
customer_reviews.text: A great manual for learning how to become strong. Between the book and starting strength YouTube video you will get strong.
customer_reviews.author: M.Seif76

customer_reviews.title: Perfect for a beginner
customer_reviews.text: This was exactly what I needed to start strength training. Thanks Mark!
customer_reviews.author: Mateo

customer_reviews.title: If you are new to weightlifting, you should read this book
customer_reviews.text: I bought this book because after doing some research online about starting to lift weights, this title kept coming up. The book is fantastic.....and very funny at times, Rippetoe has a personality that comes through well. The information in the book is presented in a way that anyone can understand, and it is VERY in depth knowledge. I would say its like the only text book you need if you want to begin a regimen of heavy weight lifting.....I have started, and I refer back to the book when I think my form may be getting out of whack.
customer_reviews.author: Marino

product_meta.title: Starting Strength: Basic Barbell Training, 3rd edition
